title: 109_hr4318
content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" allows for the termination of prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing. The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing and revokes withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for leasing purposes. SEC. 10. STATE APPROVAL REQUIREMENT WITH RESPECT TO GAS LEASING. The Secretary cannot grant gas leases within 20 miles of a state's coastline without the Governor's approval. Additionally, at least 75 percent of lease sales in each 5-year program must be for gas leasing. The amendment requires that in each 5-year program, at least 75 percent of lease sales must be for gas leasing on the available unleased acreage within each outer Continental Shelf planning area. This applies to the current 5-year program and all future programs. SEC. 4. SHARING OF REVENUES. Section 8(g) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to include provisions regarding bonus bids and royalties for new Federal gas leases on submerged lands. Under new Federal gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries established under section 4(a)(2)(A), 40% of bonus bids and royalties go to the State, while 10% is allocated to the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. Under the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act of 1981, 10% of amounts received from existing Federal gas leases on submerged lands within State boundaries established under section 4(a)(2)(A) will be paid to the State in the first full fiscal year after the enactment of the Act. Under the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act of 1981, the percentage of amounts received by the State increases in subsequent fiscal years: 10% in the first year, 20% in the second year, 30% in the third year, and 40% in the fourth year after the enactment of the Act. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act of 1981 increases the percentage of amounts received by the State in subsequent fiscal years: 10% in the first year, 20% in the second year, 30% in the third year, and 40% in the fourth year after enactment. For leased tracts partially within a State's seaward boundaries, bonus bids and royalties are subject to specific percentages based on the year after enactment. The Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act of 1981 increases State's share of bonus bids and royalties based on the percentage of surface acreage within seaward boundaries. The term 'existing Federal gas lease' refers to leases granted before the Act's enactment. The term 'new Federal gas lease' refers to a gas lease granted on or after the enactment of the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act. This applies to bonus bids and royalties received by the United States after September 30, 2006. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to establish State Seaward Boundaries for different regions. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to establish State Seaward Boundaries for different regions, including the Pacific, Gulf of Mexico, and Atlantic OCS Planning Areas. These boundaries are dated September 2005 and on file in the Office of the Director, Minerals Management Service. SEC. 5. NATURAL GAS-ONLY LEASING. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to issue leases for natural gas and associated condensate production only, with defined regulations in place. The Secretary can issue leases for natural gas and associated condensate production, with defined regulations in place for defining natural gas, condensate, and oil, establishing lessee's rights and obligations, prescribing procedures for discovering oil deposits, and setting other requirements for natural gas-only leases. The Secretary can establish requirements for natural gas-only leases, and all laws and regulations applicable to oil and natural gas leases also apply to natural gas-only leases. Existing oil and gas leases can be converted to natural gas-only leases upon request and meeting specified requirements. The Secretary can restrict development under natural gas-only leases, without amending existing oil and gas leasing programs, until June 30, 2007. The Secretary can include provisions for natural gas-only leases in the outer Continental shelf leasing program for the 5-year period starting in 2007, without being bound by any previous draft proposals.
